In this project we explore the Wi-Fi capability of the ESP 32 and understand how it can be used for Internet of Things applications through wireless communication.
The ESP 32 comes with built in Wi-Fi, allowing it to connect to a local wireless.
Network and exchange data with other devices First, the program initializes the Wi-Fi module by setting the Wi-Fi name and password so the ESP 32 can connect to the network.
Once connected, the ESP 32 reads its assigned IP address and displays it on the OLED screen, making it easy for users to access the.
Device through a browser using the web page editing library.
A simple control web interface is created where real time sensor values such as temperature can be displayed along with their units.
Each value is linked to a unique card ID to avoid conflicts between modules.
Web buttons are then added to the page.
Each assigned a specific function, like controlling an LED's or other external devices with unique card labels to separate their usage.
These buttons allow users to send commands to the ESP 32 remotely through the web interface.
After uploading the code, the OLED shows the IP address of the ESP 32.
When a computer or mobile phone connected to the same Wi-Fi network enters this IP address in a browser, the control page opens, allowing users to monitor data and control devices wirelessly.

This project demonstrates how ESP 32 can act as a powerful IoT controller, enabling real time monitoring and remote control through Wi-Fi, which is widely used in smart homes, automation systems and connected devices.
In this project, we demonstrate a Wi-Fi real time display system using the ESP 32 to monitor multiple environmental sensor values on a web page.

The ESP 32 connects to a Wi-Fi network by initializing the Wi-Fi module with the network name and password, and once connected, it obtains an IP address which is displayed on the OLED screen for easy access.

At the same time, sensors such as the temperature and humidity sensor, pressure sensor using the BMP 388 module, photo resistor for light intensity, sound sensor, PIR motion sensor, and ultrasonic sensor are initialized and read continuously.
Each sensor value is updated in real time on a web page using dedicated web display blocks where every value is assigned a label and unit so it can be clearly identified.
The OLED serves as a local display to confirm successful Wi-Fi connection, while the web page allows remote monitoring.
After uploading the code, users connect their computer or mobile phone to the same Wi-Fi network as the ESP 32 and enter the displayed IP address into a browser to view live sensor data.
If a mobile hotspot is used, the IP address can be accessed directly from the phone.

This project highlights how ESP 32 can collect data from multiple sensors and publish it wirelessly in real time, making it highly useful for smart environment monitoring, IoT dashboards, and remote sensing applications.
In this Wi-Fi piano project, we use the ESP 32 to create a simple online musical instrument that can be played through a web page.
First the Wi-Fi module and the OLED display are initialized and once the ESP 32.
Connect to the Wi-Fi network.
Its IP address is shown on the OLED so the user knows where to access the piano controls.
On the web page, 7 separate buttons are created and each button is assigned to specific musical tone.
Do, re, me, FA, so la and C These buttons are linked to the speaker.
Through the program, so when any button is pressed on the web interface, the ESP 32 receives the command and immediately plays the corresponding tone through the speaker.
Each button works independently, allowing users to press different notes in sequence to create simple melodies.
After uploading the code, any computer or mobile phone connected to the.

Same Wi-Fi network can open a browser, enter the displayed IP address and view the piano control page where pressing the buttons produces sound in real time, clearly demonstrating how Wi-Fi communication can be used to control audio output remotely using the ESP 32.

Connect to the Wi-Fi network.

Do, re, me, FA, so la and C These buttons are linked to the speaker.
Through the program, so when any button is pressed on the web interface, the ESP 32 receives the command and immediately plays the corresponding tone through the speaker.
Each button works independently, allowing users to press different notes in sequence to create simple melodies.
After uploading the code, any computer or mobile phone connected to the.

Same Wi-Fi network can open a browser, enter the displayed IP address and view the piano control page where pressing the buttons produces sound in real time, clearly demonstrating how Wi-Fi communication can be used to control audio output remotely using the ESP 32.
In this project we demonstrate Wi-Fi based control of devices using the ESP 32, where an LED, a servo motor and a fan are controlled wirelessly through a web page.
1st, the Wi-Fi module and OLED display are initialized and after a successful connection, the ESP 32's IP address is shown on the OLED screen so the user can easily access the control page.
For each device, a variable is created to store its current state, such as using a variable named rattle to represent whether the red.
LED is on or off on the web page.
Individual buttons are added for controlling the red LED, yellow LED, green LED servo, and motor.
When a button is pressed, the program checks the corresponding variable value using a condition block.
If the value is 0, the device turns on and the variable is updated.
01 and if the value is already one, the device turns off and the variable is reset to 0.
This toggle logic allows each button to switch the device state back and forth with every press.
The same method is applied to control the servo movement and the fan motor.
After uploading the code, the OLED displays the IP address.

And by connecting a computer or mobile phone to the same Wi-Fi network and entering the IP address in a browser, users can access the web interface and control all connected devices wirelessly, demonstrating a practical and easy to understand example of IoT based remote control using ESP 32.
In this video, we are going to learn how to create a voice controlled lighting system that automatically turns on an LED when it detects sound in a dark environment.
This project combines a sound sensor, a photo resistor and an LED.
To simulate a smart lighting control system similar to hallway or staircase lighting that turns on only when needed.
The photo resistor ensures that the LED does not turn on during daytime or when the light level is already bright, which helps save energy.
The sound sensor detects the volume of noise in the environment and compares it to a preset threshold.
When the sound is loud enough, for example a clap or someone speaking, the LED switches on for a few seconds and then turns off automatically.
Let us understand how the code is built.
First we drag and place the basic setup.
Blocks for reading the photoresistor and controlling the LED's.
Next we add an if condition block to check the photo resistor value.
If the analog value is lower than a threshold such as 500, meaning it is dark, the program continues to the next condition.
Inside the zip block.
We add another if condition to check the sound sensor reading.
If the sound value goes above 200, meaning a detectable sound is made, the LED turns on.
Then we insert a delay of five seconds so the LED stays lit for a short duration before turning off.
Once the code is ready and uploaded, we can test the system.
If you make loud sounds under normal lighting conditions, the LED will not turn on because the photo resistor detects brightness and blocks the signal.
However, if you cover the photo resistor to simulate darkness and then clap or speak loudly, the LED lights up for five seconds and then turns off automatically.
This project demonstrates an excellent example of combining.
Two sensors to create smart automation and energy saving behavior.
It can be applied in hallways, staircases, bedrooms, parking areas and other places.

In this project, we build an Ultrasonic Ranger by combining an ultrasonic sensor with an OLED display to create a simple and effective distance measuring device that can detect objects in the range of about four to 300 centimeters to begin.
We prepare the basic initialization blocks so the program runs continuously, and then we initialize the OLED module to enable text display.
Next, we set the OLED text size to 12 by 16 so the information is clearly visible on the screen.
After that we declare A variable named distance and assign it the value detected.
By the ultrasonic sensor allowing the system to constantly update the measured distance in real time before displaying new data, we clear any existing content on the OLED to avoid overlapping text.

Then we add display blocks to show the label distance on the first line of the OLED screen, followed by the actual distance value on the second line, and finally add the unit CM after the number so the reading is easy to understand.
To make sure the displayed information updates properly, we include an OLED refresh block at the end of the loop.
Once the code is uploaded, the OLED screen immediately begins showing the distance detected by the ultrasonic sensor, updating continuously as objects move closer or farther away.
This project demonstrates how ultrasonic sensors can be used for accurate distance measurement and how an OLED module can present sensor data, clearly making it a useful foundation.
For applications such as obstacle detection, parking assistants, robotics, and smart measuring tools.
In this smart control panel project, we use the ESP 32's built-in Wi-Fi feature to create an intelligent web-based control system that can both control devices and display sensor data wirelessly.
First, the Wi-Fi module.
OLED display are initialized and once the ESP 32 connects to the Wi-Fi network, its IP address is shown on the OLED screen so the user can easily access the control panel.
On the web page.
Different display cards are created to show real time values from connected modules such as sensors, allowing users to monitor environmental.
Our system data remotely.
Along with this, multiple web buttons are defined and each button is assigned to specific functions such as turning LED S on or off, controlling A servo motor, or operating other connected modules.
When a button is pressed on the web interface, the ESP 32 receives the command instantly and performs the assigned.
Action demonstrating real time wireless control.

After uploading the program, any mobile phone or computer connected to the same Wi-Fi network can open a browser, enter the displayed IP address and access the Smart Control panel where both device control and live data monitoring are combined into a single, easy to use interface.
Clearly showing how ESP 32 can be used to build practical IoT control systems.

In this project, we create a creative and informal RGB ring clock that uses an RGB LED ring to represent time through colors, where red indicates the hour, green shows the minute, and blue displays the seconds and because the ring.
12 LEDs.
Each bead represents A5 second or five minute interval, making the clock simple yet visually appealing.
We start the build by preparing the basic blocks, initializing the serial port at 9600 baud and setting up the RGB ring module.
Then we declare 3 variables named our minute.
And 2nd assigning them initial values like 10/30/40.
After this basic setup we create a custom function called clock code which handles the entire time counting logic.
Inside this function we increment the second value every second and check if seconds reach 60.
If they do we reset seconds to 0.
And increase the minute by 1.
Similarly if minutes reach 60 we reset them and increase the hour, and if hours exceed 12 we roll them back to 1.
With this logical structure, the clock stays in the standard 12 hour format.
We then add a one second delay to ensure real time counting and print the updated time values on the serial monitor for reference.
After the time tracking part, we start programming the RGB ring to display the time visually.
For the seconds, we check whether 2nd modulo 5 = 0.
If it is 0, the 12th bead lights up and for all other values we light the bead corresponding to 2nd slash 5 -, 1 with blue representing seconds.
The same idea is applied to minutes, but without the clear block condition, and green LED's represent the minutes.
For the hours, we directly map the hour value to the bead number using hour one, since  to  corresponds neatly to beads 0 to 11 and these are displayed in red.
Finally, after preparing all timing and.
LED mapping logic.
We refresh the RGB ring so that the correct bead lights up for each unit of time.

Once the code is uploaded and an initial time is entered, the RGB ring begins functioning like a colorful analog clock, with blue completing a full circle every minute, green showing minute progress, and red marking our positions.
When colors overlap, only one is visible depending on priority, maintaining clarity.
Although this project doesn't use a real time clock chip, it still serves as an excellent demonstration of how to combine LED's variables arithmetic.

In this project, we learn how to control a servo motor using the X axis of a joystick, a method commonly used in real applications such as remotely opening or closing doors and switching mechanical devices on or off to build this.
Rogram We start with the basic initialization blocks, so the system runs continuously.
Then we declare A variable named angle and assign it the X axis value read from the joystick, which changes depending on whether the joystick is moved left or right.
Inside the main loop, we use conditional logic to check the value of angle.
When the joystick is pushed to the right, the X axis value becomes very high, typically greater than 3500, and under this condition the servo rotates to 0.
When the joystick is pushed to the left, the X axis value becomes.
Very low, usually less than 500, and in this case the servo rotates to 180.
These two conditions allow the servo to respond directly to joystick movement, creating a simple and effective remote control system.
After uploading the completed code, you can test the project by moving the joystick left and right.
Pushing it to the left causes the servo to rotate to 180, while pushing it to the right makes the servo.
Rotate back to 0.

This project demonstrates how analog joystick input can be converted into precise mechanical motion, and it helps you understand the relationship between sensor readings, variables, conditional statements, and servo motor control, and practical automation and robotics applications.
Intrusion alarm is a security system designed to detect unauthorized entry into a protected area and alert people immediately.
It is commonly used in homes, shops, warehouses, supermarkets, and many other places to ensure safety of people.
Property In this project, Air motion sensor is used to sense human movement.
When the system is powered on, the sensor continuously monitors the surroundings.
If any motion is detected, the PIR sensor outputs a high value which activates the alarm system.
As a result, the speaker starts sounding an alert, the red LED turns on to indicate danger and the green LED turns off when there is no movement.
The P IR sensor outputs a low value, the speaker remains silent, the red LED stays off, and the green LED turns on to show normal condition.
This intrusion.
Alarm system provides a simple and effective way to monitor restricted areas and improve security.

In this project, we create a human body piano that uses an ultrasonic sensor to detect the distance of your hand and place different musical notes based on how far your hand is from the sensor, turning your hand movements into a fun and interactive piano.
The system includes an ultrasonic sensor for distance measurement, A variable named distance to store the detected value, and a speaker to play the tones.
To build the code manually, start with a when green flag clicked block and add a forever loop so the sensor continuously reads the distance.
Then assign the ultrasonic sensor value to the distance variable.
Next, use a series of IF conditions to check different distance ranges.

If the distance is between 5 to 10 centimeters play due between 10 to 15 centimeters play RE, 15 to 20 centimeters play ME, 20 to 25 centimeters play FA, 25 to 30 centimeters play SO 30 to 35 centimeters play LA.
And 35 to 40 centimeters play C.
Duplicate the same structure for all 7 notes, adjusting the distance conditions accordingly.
And finally add a block to stop the tone when your hand moves out of the note ranges.
Once uploaded, place your hand in front of the sensor and slowly move it closer or farther to play different tones.
The speaker responds instantly, allowing you to create melodies, experiment with rhythm, or slide your hand to produce a smooth musical scale.
This project helps you learn how ultrasonic sensors, variables, loops, and conditional statements work together, making it both educational and fun.
It's a great example of how coding and music can combine to create an engaging STEM activity, and you can even extend it later by adding LED's or display screens to enhance the experience.
In this video tutorial, we will learn how to create a mini environment monitoring device that displays temperature, humidity, air pressure, and altitude using an OLED screen.
We begin by building the two basic setup blocks and then initialize.
Built the BMP 388 sensor and the OLED display.
Next we add a string block to set the required parameters.
After that we read the BMP 388 sensor values and start displaying information on the OLED.
On the first line, we center the text data Suggs by setting the cursor to around X = 30.
Then we set the display position starting from y = 10 and add 3 OLED display blocks.
The first block shows T for temperature in mill warp mode, the next block displays the actual temperature value, and the third block shows the unit.
See in warp mode we duplicate this structure to display humidity where the first line shows our H.
The second line shows the humidity value and the third line displays the unit per cent.
We repeat the same steps again for air pressure, using P on the first line, the pressure value on the second line, and the unit HPA on the third line.
Finally, we duplicate once more for altitude, starting with ASL on the 1st.
The altitude value on the second line and the unit M on the third line.
To finish the project, we add an OLED refresh block and a one second delay so the values update smoothly.

After uploading the complete code, the OLED display will continuously show real time temperature, humidity, air pressure and altitude, turning your setup into a compact environmental monitoring device.
In this project, we create a digital compass using the AK-8975 magnetic sensor and an OLED display to visually indicate direction with arrows.
First, the program begins with the basic initialization blocks, so the system.
Runs continuously.
We then initialize both the AKA 8975 Compass module and the OLED display and declare A variable named direction to store the heading value measured by the sensor inside the loop.
The OLED screen is cleared to ensure a clean display and the direction value read from the AK-8975.
Module is assigned to the direction variable based on this value.
Conditional blocks are used to determine which arrows should be displayed on the OLED.
When the direction value is between  and 360, an upward arrow is shown indicating N if the direction falls between 230.

And 250, a right arrow appears representing E When the direction value is between  and 170, a downward arrow is displayed indicating South and if the direction is between 70 and 90, a left arrow appears representing W after selecting the.
Direct Arrow, An OLED refresh block updates the display and a short delay of half a second is added to ensure smooth and stable readings.
Once the code is uploaded, the OLED arrow initially points close to the self direction and as the coding box is rotated, the arrow changes accordingly, clearly showing real time directional movement.
This project demonstrates how a magnetic sensor can be used for compass applications and how sensor data can be converted into intuitive visual indicators.
Making it useful for navigation systems, robotics and orientation based projects.

In this project we create a mini car backing radar that works just like the reversing sensors used in real vehicles, using an ultrasonic sensor to detect the distance behind the car, a traffic light LED module for visual alerts and a speaker.
For sound warnings.
We begin by building the basic coding blocks and then declare A variable named distance which stores the value detected by the ultrasonic sensor.
The program continuously updates this value so the system always knows how far the obstacle is.
Next, we add a condition to check if the distance is greater than 40 centimeters.
If it is, the system shows a safe situation by turning on the green LED's, keeping the red LED off, and making sure the speaker stays silent.
Then we add another condition for when the distance is less than 40 centimeters.
In this case, the system recognizes danger, so the red LED turns on, the green LED turns off, and the speaker starts beeping to warn that an obstacle is too close.
After uploading the program, testing becomes very simple.
When the sensor detects a larger safe distance, only the green light glows and no sound is produced.
But when something approaches too closely, the warning light and alarm activate immediately.
This project clearly demonstrates how ultrasonic sensing, conditional logic and output modules work together to create a real world safety device.
It shows how the ultrasonic sensor acts like the eyes, constantly checking for objects, while the LED's and speaker act like the signals and voice that guide the user.

Even though this is a small scale model, it works on the same principle used in modern cars to avoid collisions while reversing, making it an excellent beginner friendly example of applying sensors and programming to solve real problems effectively.
In this project we create a button controlled fan system where the fan turns on or off depending on which button is pressed, using an add key input to read different analog values from each button.
To build the code manually, we start with the basic setup.
Blocks the when green flag clicked block and a forever loop, so the fan continuously responds to button presses.
Next we create a variable named item and inside the loop we assign the analog value from the AD key sensor to this variable.
The AD key module gives different analog readings for different buttons.
So we use an if else condition to read these values and decide what the fan should do if the value of item is greater than 3500, which corresponds to pressing the red button.
We stop the fan by setting both motor pins low if the value is between 2030.
Which corresponds to pressing the yellow button.
We activate the fan by making the motor rotate.
These conditions allow the system to instantly react to whichever button the user presses.
After deciding the fan state.

We add a short delay of around 0.3 seconds to prevent rapid fluctuations in readings and make the button response smooth once uploaded to the board, Pressing the yellow button makes the fan spin and pressing the red button.
Turns it off, showing how simple button inputs can be used to control real hardware.
This activity teaches how analog key modules work, how to read sensor values, and how conditions and motor control instructions together can create an efficient interactive device.
It's a fun introduction to digital input control and a practical demonstration of using buttons to manage electrical appliances in a safe and programmable way.
In this video tutorial, we will learn how to create an automatic fan system that works using both temperature sensing and motion detection to save energy.
During hot summer days, many public places use auto fans that turn on only when the surrounding temperature becomes too high.
In this project, we will enhance that idea by adding a PIR motion sensor so the fan will run only when the temperature crosses the threshold and a person is detected nearby.
1st we create the basic setup blocks and then we declare A variable named temp.
Next we read the temperature sensor value and assign it to the temp variable so the program can continuously check the environment.
Then we add an if else block to compare the temperature value with the set limit such as 28.
If the value is higher, the program proceeds to the next condition.
If not, the fan remains off.
After that we add another if else block to read the P IR sensor.
If the par value is 1, meaning motion is detected, the fan turns on.
Otherwise it remains off after uploading the complete test code.
The system works automatically whenever the temperature rises above 28 and the PIR sensor detects someone the fan starts were tating.
If either condition is not met, temperature too low, or no motion detected, the fan stays off, ensuring efficient and smart energy usage.
In this activity, we create an automatic door system similar to those found in malls, where the door opens when a person approaches and closes when no one is near by.
To build this program, we start with the basic initialization blocks.
Using the green flag and a forever loop to make sure the system keeps checking for movement.
Inside the loop we add a condition block to read the output of the PIR motion sensor.
This sensor detects infrared radiation from human bodies, and it outputs one when someone is present and 0 when the area is clear.
Based on this reading, we control a servo motor that represents the door.
When the PR sensor detects motion, the servo rotates to 180, which simulates the door opening.
When no motion is detected, the servo returns to 0, closing the door.
By continuously evaluating the sensor values, the door responds automatically to people approaching and leaving.
After uploading the code, simply wave your hand in front of the PIR sensor and the servo turns to 180, opening the door.
As soon as the center no longer detects movement, the servo slowly returns.
In this project we create a simple access control system using an RFID module, a magnetic or IC card and a servo motor to simulate a real access door.
The idea is that when the correct card is scanned, the door opens automatically and if the card is not recognized, the door stays locked.
To build the program, we begin with the basic start and forever blocks, so the system constantly checks for a card.
We initialize the RFID module so it can read card data, and then we create a string variable called ID card that stores the correct card code.
Each user will have a different code, so you must replace the sample code with the one read from your own card.
Inside the forever loop, we use a condition that compares the scanned RFID code with the stored.
ID card value.
If the scanned code matches, it means the card is authorized and the servo rotates to 180 representing the door opening.
The servo holds this position for three seconds to allow the person to enter.
After the delay, the servo returns to 0, closing the door again.
If the scant card does not match the stored code, the condition fails and the servo remains at 0, indicating that the door is locked and access is denied.
After uploading the program, simply place your card near the RFID sensor.
If it is the correct card, the servo will smoothly rotate to open the door and then return to the closed position.
If the card is incorrect, nothing happens demonstrating reliable and secure access control.

This experiment clearly shows how RFID technology, variables and conditional logic can work together to build real world security systems similar to those used in offices, apartments and commercial buildings.
In this video tutorial, we are going to learn how to build an automatic window closing system that reacts to changes in light.
This project uses a photo resistor as a light sensor and a servo motor to open and close the window.
The idea behind the project is simple.
When the surrounding environment becomes dark, the system should automatically close the window for safety and energy efficiency.
The photo resistor plays a key role in detecting light intensity because its resistance changes according to the ambient light level.
We set a threshold value that determines when the window.
Would close if the analog value of the photo resistor drops below this threshold, meaning the environment is dark, the servo rotates to 180, simulating the closing of the window.
Otherwise, when the value is higher than the threshold indicating daylight or sufficient brightness, the servo returns to 0.
Opening the window now, let's discuss the block coding process.
We begin by placing the basic initialization blocks for reading the photo resistor and controlling the servo motor.
Then we insert an IF condition block to compare the analog input value.
Inside the if section, we add the servo control block and set the rotation.
The 180 for the dark condition.
In the L section, we again add the servo block and set its rotation to 0 for the bright condition.
After completing the code and uploading it, we can test the system by covering the photo resistor with our hand or any object.
When the light decreases, the threshold is crossed.
And the servo rotates to 180, closing the window.
When the cover is removed and the analog value becomes higher than the threshold, the servo moves back to 0, opening the window again.
This automatic window system demonstrates an excellent real world application of sensors and actuators, showing how automation can improve.
Everyday life.

In this video tutorial we will learn about the 9 gram servo motor, its working principle, wiring and how to control it using block coding.
A9 gram servo is a small but powerful motor used in robotics.
Projects for its high precision and good torque.
It can rotate up to 180 and operates with low noise.
The servo has three wires.
The brown wire is G&D connected to ground.
The red wire is VCC connected to five volts or 3.3 volts power supply and the orange.
Wire is the signal pin which receives PWM pulse width modulation signals to control the rotation angle.
The servo angle is determined by the pulse width, where one millisecond rotates the servo to 0 and two milliseconds rotates it to 180.
Now let us move to coating first place.
Servo control block and set the degree to zero and delay to two seconds.
Duplicate the block and change the angle to 90 and again duplicate to change the angle to 180.
Finally duplicate once more to bring the servo back to 0.
After uploading the servo will rotate to zero 90 and 180.
Each staying for two seconds and then repeat.
For the extension activity, we gradually rotate the servo from zero to 180 using a repeat block set to 180.
Then place the servo angle block inside and increase the degree step by step with a delay of 10 milliseconds.
Duplicate this block and change the increase to decrease to move the servo back from 180 to 0.
When the code is uploaded, the servo will smoothly rotate forward and backward continuously.
Servo motors are widely used in robotic arms, grippers, steering mechanisms, aircraft models, and many mechanical.
Systems.

It combines both temperature and pressure.
Portable and mobile applications.

Is widely used.
Wearable devices, smart home systems, and other consumer electronics.
It can be optimized further to improve power consumption, resolution and filtering performance based on piezoelectric pressure sensing technology, the BMP 380.
8 measures air pressure and temperature accurately.
It can measure pressure ranging from 300 to 1250 hectopascals while consuming very low power only 3.4 micro amperes at A1 Hertz operating frequency.
The built in.
Infinite Impulse response filter helps reduce external interference effects and ensures smooth readings.

PIR motion sensor.
The PIR motion sensor uses the RE-200 BP sensing element.
It works based on the pyroelectric effect, which means it can detect infrared radiation naturally released.
By a human body or an animal, with the help of a Fresnel lens, the sensor can detect motion from a greater distance and over a wider area.
When a person or an animal moves within its sensing range, the PIR sensor outputs a high signal.
When no motion is present, it outputs a low signal.
The programming blocks shown demonstrate how to read the PIR sensor value and use it inside an IF and else structure.
The code checks whether motion is detected.
If the condition is true, the instructions inside the IF section will run.
If the condition is false, the code inside the L section will run.
To test the PIR sensor code, you can either load the prepared file directly from your computer or manually build the blocks yourself.

You then add the serial block and set the board rate as needed.
Inside a forever loop you insert an if and else block.

From the PIR category you select the block that reads.
The PIR motion sensor value from the chosen interface pin.
This block is then placed inside the condition area of the IF structure.
If motion is detected, you can program the system to send a message through the serial monitor, such as printing the words someone.
If no motion is detected the code.
Inside the else portion will run instead printing the message no one.
Now let us understand how to complete the test code for the PIR motion sensor.
After adding the print some one block under the if section, we also need to add the print no one block under the L section.
This ensures that the system responds correctly.
Based on whether motion is detected or not, once both blocks are placed in the correct positions, the program becomes complete.
The forever loop continuously checks for movement.
If motion is detected by the PIR sensor, the system prints the word someone in the serial monitor.
If no movement is detected, the system prints the message No one.
This completed code allows us to clearly observe how the PIR sensor responds in real time.
When we upload the code to Arduino and open the serial monitor, we can see the live output as a person moves in front of the.
Sensor the serial monitor prints someone.
When no motion is detected, the serial monitor prints no one.
This helps verify that the sensor and the code are working correctly.

Hello everyone, in this video we are going to create Project 19 dimming lamp where we control the brightness of an LED using a potentiometer and an Arduino ESP 32 board to begin.

Block which reads the analog value from pin IO 33 and maps it from a range of 0 to 4095 into 0 to 255.

Was turned for the wiring.

The LED is connected with its positive terminal to IO25 and its negative terminal to ground.
Enabling the ESP 32 to control the LED using a PWM signal.
The potentiometer works by changing its resistance, which alters the voltage across it.
The ESP 32 reads this voltage as a value between 0 and 4095, then converts it into a value between 0 and 200.

55 to adjust the LED brightness after completing the wiring and uploading the program to the board, rotating the potentiometer changes the LED brightness smoothly from dim to bright, confirming that the dimming lamp project is working successfully.

The 130 motor is a simple DC motor module that can be directly connected to the Control Board without using an extra driver, making it ideal for small DIY projects.
It works on a voltage range of 3.3 to 5 volts.
And its speed can be smoothly controlled using PWM.
By changing the PWM duty cycle, the average voltage applied to the motor changes, which directly controls the rotation speed.
The motor has two control pins, INA and INB, and the direction of rotation depends on which pin has the higher PWM.
Value.
If I and B has a higher PWM value than INA, the motor rotates clockwise and if INA has a higher PWM value than inb, it rotates counterclockwise.
When both pins are set to 0, the motor stops.
In this set, the motor is connected to port 9, where Ina is linked to IO 18 and INB to ion 19.
In the program, the motor is first initialized and then inside a continuous loop it runs clockwise at full speed, slows down, stops and then repeats the same sequence in the opposite direction.
This experiment clearly demonstrates how PWM can be used to control both the speed and direction of a DC motor safely and effectively.
This experiment demonstrates the working of a capacitive touch sensor module which allows touch based switching without any mechanical parts.
The sensor uses a capacitive area that detects changes in capacitance when a finger touches it.
Enabling reliable touch detection.

The module operates on a DC voltage of 3.3 to 5 volts, consumes very low current.
And outputs a digital signal.

When the capacitive area is touched, the sensor outputs a high signal and the onboard red LED turns on and when the touch is released.
The output goes low and the LED turns off.

You press the button.

This project uses the DS18B20 digital temperature sensor to accurately measure environmental temperature and display the result through the serial monitor.
The DS18B20 is a compact, high precision sensor with strong.
Anti interference capability and a wide detection range from -55C to plus 125C, making it reliable for many applications.
Since it is a digital module with a blue housing, it is connected to a digital port on the Control Board and in this setup it is attached to port 6 which corresponds to digital pin.
IO23 In the program, the temperature sensor library is first added and the serial port is initialized so that data can be displayed correctly inside a continuous loop.
The system reads the temperature value detected by the D18B20 and prints it to the serial monitor without wrapping, ensuring that the numeric value.
And its unit appear on the same line.

A digital temperature sensing and serial output worked together in a simple and effective way.
This project explains the working of the Five Channel AD Button module which is designed to save input ports by allowing 5 different buttons to be read using only one analog pin.
The module works on the principle of voltage division, where.
Pressing each button produces a different output voltage.
This voltage is read by the board's built in ADC, which converts the analog signal into a digital value.
Since the board uses a 12 bit ADC with a 3.3 Volt reference, the analog input is converted into values ranging from zero to 4095.
In this set, the module is connected to the analog port 8 which corresponds to IO34.
Inside the program, the pin mode is set and the serial port is initialized first.
Then in a continuous loop, the analog value from IO34IS read and stored in a variable and this value is printed on the serial monitor.
Using conditional checks, the program compares the ADC value with predefined ranges to identify which button is pressed.
If the value is below 500, it indicates that.
L button is pressed.
Values between 501,000 indicate SW-51000 to 2000 indicate SW-42000 to 3000 indicate SW three, 3000 to 4000 indicate SW 2 and 4000 to 5000 indicate SW1A.
Short delay is added to refresh the readings.

Smoothly after uploading the code and setting the baud rate correctly, pressing different buttons displays the corresponding analog values and button names on the serial monitor, clearly demonstrating how multiple buttons can be detected using a single analog input.
The IR receiver module is used to receive signals from an infrared remote control and convert them into digital data that the Control Board can understand.
It works on a voltage range of 3.3 to 5 volts and is designed to receive standard.
38 kHz infrared signals commonly used in TV's, air conditioners and other remote controlled devices.
The transmitter sends modulated infrared light and the receiver detects this light, converts it into electrical signals and decodes the command.
Since it is a digital module, it is connected to a digital port on the board.
In this set, the IR receiver is connected to port one, where the signal pin is linked to IO 13.
In the program, the serial monitor is first initialized and the IR receiver pin is set inside a continuous loop.
The program checks whether a signal has been received when a button on the remote is pressed.
The receiver captures the signal and prints the corresponding key value in hexadecimal format on the serial monitor.
A short delay is added to avoid repeated readings from a single button press, and the receiver is refreshed so it can receive the next command.
This experiment demonstrates how infrared communication can be used to control robots.
And electronic projects wirelessly.
Hello everyone, today we will learn about manual control mode where we control a fan using a capacitive touch sensor and a 130 motor.
In this project the fan works in manual mode, meaning we start and stop it.
They simply touching the sensor.
First we connect the board to the computer and upload the program.
Then we focus on understanding how the logic works.
We begin by importing the DC motor library for ESP 32 and setting the touch sensor pin to IO 27.
Next, we create a variable called press and set its initial value to 0, which helps us track whether the fan is currently off or on.
Inside the forever loop, the program continuously checks the state of the touch sensor using a digital read.
When the sensor is touched and the value at IO27 becomes one, the program checks the value of the press variable.
If press is 0, it means the fan is currently off, so the motor is activated using the motor analog write block.
The fan starts rotating and the press variable is updated to 1.
When the sensor is touched again and IO27 reads one while press is already won, the program understands that the fan is running, so it stops the motor and resets press back to 0.
In this way, each touch acts like a toggle switch.
One touch turns the fan on and the next touch turns it off.
After uploading the code, we can test the project easily.
Touching the capacitive module once starts the fan and touching it again stops the fan.
This project clearly demonstrates how variables conditions.
And continuous loops work together to create a simple and effective manual control system using a touch sensor.
This experiment explains the working of a photo interrupter module, which operates using a builtin light source and a light receiver to detect interruptions in a light path.
The module contains an LED as the light emitter and a photosensitive receiver with a signal.
Amplifier and When an object passes through the groove and blocks the light, the receiver detects no light, causing a change in resistance that is converted into a digital electrical signal.
The photo interrupter works on a DC voltage of 3.3 to 5 volts, draws about 20-4 milliamps of current, and outputs a digital signal, making it suitable for precise.
Object detection and counting applications.
Since it has blue housing, it is connected to a digital port of the main board and in this setup it is connected to port 3 which corresponds to digital pin IO 26.
When the light path is blocked, the module outputs a high signal and when the path is clear it outputs a low signal.
In the program, the pin mode and serial communication are initialized 1st and variables are created to store the current sensor state, the previous state, and a counter value.
Inside a continuous loop.
The system repeatedly reads the digital value from IO26 with a short delay to stabilize the readings, compares the current state with the last state.
And detects changes caused by an object entering or leaving the groove.
Each time the light is interrupted, meaning the state changes from low to high, the counter is increased by 1 and the updated count is printed on the serial monitor.
After processing, the current state is stored as the last state for the next cycle once the code is uploaded.
In the correct BOD rate is set.

Placing and removing an opaque object through the sensor groove will result in the serial monitor displaying the number of times the light has been interrupted, demonstrating accurate detection and counting of passing objects.
Hello everyone, today we will learn how to control a fan using an IR remote by building the logic step by step with drag and drop programming blocks.
In this project we use events, variables, IR operators, motor and control blocks to read signals from the remote and control the fan speed.
We begin by importing the DC motor and IR remote libraries, then initialize 4 variables.

Key one_press_number key 2_press_number key three_press_number and, key with initial values of 0 where the first 3 variables store how many times keys 1-2 and three are pressed and the last variable stores the value received from the IR receiver while ina AND inb.
Are set to 0 and the IR receiver pin is INITIALIZED as IO13Inside the forever loop, the program continuously checks whether an infrared signal is received.
When a signal arrives, the received value is stored in the key variable and the IR receiver is refreshed.
If key one is detected, key one_press_number increases by 1 and the other two key variables are reset to 0.

The fan at high speed, key 2 at medium speed, key three at low speed, and pressing the same key again stops the fan, clearly demonstrating how variables, conditions, loops and IR control work together.
In a practical project.

This experiment introduces the RGB LED module with a common anode, which combines three LED's, red, green and blue into a single unit to produce a wide range of colors, including white by mixing these primary colors.
In different proportions based on trichromatic theory.
Unlike a white LED that emits white light directly, an RGB LED generates colors through additive color mixing, where equal intensities of red, green, and blue light produce white.
The module operates on a DC voltage of 3.3 to 5 volts, consumes about 19.5.
Milliamperes of current and is designed to work within a temperature range of -10 to plus 50C.
It has four pins, 3 control pins for red, green and blue, and one common anode pin that connects to the positive power supply.
In this setup the RGB LED module is connected to a white port.
On the main board, specifically port one where the red pen connects to IO12, the green pin to IO13, and the blue pen to IO 14.
Each color is controlled digitally, so setting a pin high turns the corresponding color on, while setting it low turns it off.
After initializing the pins as outputs the main program.
Runs in a continuous loop where the LED lights up red, then green, then blue, and finally white, with each color displayed for one second.
Once the code is uploaded successfully, the visible result is an RGB LED smoothly cycling through red, green, blue, and white colors in a repeating sequence.
This temperature detection system automatically controls a fan based on the surrounding temperature.
It uses a D18B20 temperature sensor to continuously monitor the temperature and A130DC motor to drive the fan.
The temperature sensor reads the current temperature and sends the value to the Control Board, where it is also displayed on the serial monitor.
In the program, a temperature threshold of 30C is set, which can be adjusted as needed.
When the detected temperature rises above 30C, the Control Board activates the motor using PWM.
Causing the fan to rotate and cool the system.
When the temperature drops to 30C or below, the motor stops and the fan turns off automatically.
This setup demonstrates how sensors and motors can work together to create an automatic cooling system similar to those used in electronic devices and smart machines.

This project introduces the TM 1654 digit tube display module which uses a 0.36 inch red common cathode digital display driven by the TM1650 chip.
The key advantage of this module is that it only requires.
2 signal wires to communicate with the main board using A2 wire serial protocol, which is similar to but not exactly the same as standard I2C, helping to save IO pins.
The module operates at 3.3 to 5 volts and is connected to the green ports on the board after importing the TM1650 display library.
In the program, the display is first initialized, cleared and then turned on and an integer variable I is defined with an initial value of 0.
Inside a continuous loop, the program checks whether the value of I is less than 999.
If it is, the value of I is converted into a string and displayed on the 4 digit tube.
Then I is increased by one.
If I reaches 999, it is reset back to zero so the counting can start again.
A short delay of 0.01 seconds is added to control the refresh speed of the display.
After uploading the code, the digital tube continuously counts from zero to 999.
And then repeats, clearly demonstrating how numbers can be displayed and refreshed smoothly using the TM 1654 digit tube module.
This trigger mode system allows the fan to turn on automatically when an object comes close to it.
It uses an ultrasonic sensor to measure the distance of nearby objects and A130DC motor to drive the fan.
The ultrasonic sensor continuously sends out sound waves and calculates the distance based on the reflected signal, while the measured distance is displayed on the serial monitor.
In the program, a distance threshold of 10 centimeters is set, which can be changed according to requirements when the detected distance becomes less than 10 centimeters.
The Control Board activates the motor using PWM, causing the fan to rotate.
When the distance is equal to or greater than 10 centimeters, the motor stops and the fan turns off.
This experiment demonstrates how distance sensing can be used to trigger automatic actions similar to touchless fans and smart safety systems.
It also helps learners understand sensor integration, real time decision making, and motor control and automation projects.
This project demonstrates how an ultrasonic sensor is used to measure the distance between the sensor and an object by mimicking the natural echolocation ability of bats.
The sensor works by sending out ultrasonic sound waves at a frequency of 40 kHz.
When these waves hit an obstacle, they are reflected back to the sensor.
By measuring the time taken for the sound waves to travel to the object and return, the system calculates the distance accurately.
In this setup, the ultrasonic sensor operates at 5 volts and can measure distances ranging from 2cm up to 400 centimeters.

Since the ultrasonic module cannot be connected directly to the board, a converter module is used and the sensor is connected to port 7 where the trigger pin is linked to IO16 and the echo pin to IO35.
In the program, the ultrasonic library is added and the serial port is initialized first.
Inside a continuous loop, the system reads the distance detected by the sensor and prints the value on the serial monitor.
A short delay is added to refresh the reading smoothly.
After uploading the code, the serial monitor continuously displays the real time distance between the ultrasonic sensor and the nearby obstacle, clearly showing.
While ultrasonic ranging works in practical applications.

Hello everyone, in this project we are going to explore variable speed mode where we control the rotation speed of a small fan using a 5 channel AD button module and A130 motor after connecting the board.
And uploading the program.
The system works by first initializing the required pin modes and starting the serial port for monitoring values.
Inside the main loop, the program continuously reads the analog values from the AD button module to detect which button is pressed.
Each button corresponds to a different speed level when button 5.
Pressed the fan speed is set to 40%, button four sets it to 60%, button three sets it to 80% and button 2 sets it to 100%, while button one stops the fan completely.
To achieve accurate speed control, the program uses a map function which converts the speed range of zero to 100 into the PWM.
Range of 0 to 255.
Since motor speed depends on the PWM duty cycle, this means each speed unit is mapped proportionally to a PWM value, allowing smooth and precise control without manual calculations.
The mapped PWM value is then sent to the motor using the motor analog write block.
Making the fan rotate at the selected speed.
By duplicating the same logic for different speed values, we can easily create multiple speed levels.
After uploading the code.
Pressing buttons from  to  increases the fan speed step by step from 40% to 100%, and pressing button one turns the fan off, clearly demonstrating.
While analog input mapping and PWM work together to implement an effective variable speed control system.
This experiment explains how the white LED module works and how it is controlled using the Easy Plug Control Board.
An LED, or light emitting diode converts electrical energy into light and is commonly used as an indicator or display.
Element with different materials producing different colors such as red, green, yellow, and blue.
The white LED module operates on 3.3 to 5 volts using a digital control signal and connects to a telephone socket interface.
Since modules with blue housing are digital, the white LED is connected to a digital port.
And in this setup it is connected to port one, which corresponds to digital pin IO 13.
The pin mode of IO 13 is set to output so the main board can send high or low signals to the LED's inside a continuous loop.
The pin is set HIGH to turn the LED on, followed by a one second delay, then set LOW to turn the LED.
Off followed by another one second delay.

This sequence repeats continuously, causing the LED to blink with a one second interval, and after uploading the code successfully, the result is a white LED that turns ON for one second and OFF for one second repeatedly.

In this project we are building an LDR light detection project using an LDR sensor and Arduino.

Today we are going to learn a very exciting project.
Bluetooth controlled RGB LED using HC 05 and Arduino.
This project helps us understand wireless communication.
And how we can control devices remotely using a smartphone.
In this project, we use an HC05 Bluetooth module to send commands from a mobile phone to the Arduino.
The Arduino receives these commands and controls A4 pin RGB LED accordingly.
An RGB LED contains 3 colors inside it.
Red, green, and blue.
By turning these colors on and off in different combinations, we can create many different colors like red, green, blue, yellow, cyan, magenta, and white.
In our program, we use the software serial library to create a virtual Bluetooth communication channel on digital pins.
and  This allows the Arduino to talk to the HC 05 module.
We define 3 pins, 6 for red, 7 for green and eight for blue and set them as output in the setup function.
Initially, all colors are turned off in the loop function.
The Arduino continuously listens for incoming Bluetooth data.
When we send a letter from the mobile app, the Arduino reads it and performs the corresponding action.
If we send our, the RED LED turns on.
If we send our, the RED LED turns off.
Similarly, G&G control the green LED's and B&B control the blue LED's.
We can also send W to turn on all three colors together, which makes white light.
If we send oh all colors turn off.
This type of system is used in smart lighting, decorative lights, stage lighting, and home automation projects.
It helps students understand serial communication, Bluetooth technology, and digital output control.
After uploading the code, we pair our phone with the HC0.
Live module and use a Bluetooth app to send commands instantly.
We can control different colors wirelessly.
Congratulations, you have successfully built a Bluetooth controlled RGB LED system.
Keep learning and keep building with with Robo.

In today's project we are going to learn how to interface a push button with a nice superscript 2C LCD display using Arduino.

Similarly, in digital attendance systems or ticket machines, pressing a button triggers a message on the screen.
To build this project, we use an Arduino Uno, a push button, and a 16 by two I Superscript 2C LCD display.
The I Superscript 2C LCD reduces wiring complexity by using only two data lines.
SDA and SCL along with power and ground.

This project is an RGB LED color control system using Arduino.
The main objective of this project is to demonstrate how different colors can be produced using a single RGB LED by controlling its three primary color components.
Red, Green and Blue.
The RGB LED has three internal LEDs, Red, Green and Blue, which are connected to the Arduino through current limiting resistors.
By turning these LED's on and off in different combinations, we can generate multiple colors such as red, green, blue, yellow, cyan, magenta, and white.
The Arduino is programmed to automatically cycle through different colors at regular intervals, creating a smooth and visually attractive lighting effect.
This project helps students understand digital output control, color mixing, and basic microcontroller programming.
It can be used in decorative lighting, mood lighting systems and creative electronic displays.
This project is a gas detection system using the MQ 135 gas sensor and Arduino.
The main objective of this system is to monitor air quality and warn users when harmful gases are present.
The MQ 135.
Sensor continuously detects gases such as ammonia, smoke, carbon dioxide and other pollutants.
It sends an analog signal to the Arduino which is processed and displayed on a 16 by two I Superscript 2C LCD screen in real time.
When the gas level exceeds A predefined safe limit, the system turns on an LED as a visual warning.
If the gas level is normal, the LED remains off and the LCD displays normal air.
This project is useful in homes, kitchens, laboratories, industries, and safety monitoring systems and help students.
Understand sensor interfacing, analog data processing and real time monitoring using Arduino.
This project is a password protected appliance control system using Arduino designed to provide security and controlled access to electrical appliances.
In this system a 16 by two I Superscript 2C LCD.
2 push buttons, a relay module and a letter interfaced with an Arduino Uno.
The user enters A4 digit password using only two buttons.
1 button is used to increment the digit from zero to 9 and the second button is used to confirm and move to the next digit.
The entered password is compared with the pre stored password in the Arduino.
If the password is correct, the relay is activated allowing the connected appliance to turn on.
If the password is incorrect, the lead gives an alert indicating unauthorized access.
All system status messages such as enter, password, access granted or wrong password are displayed on the LCD.
This project demonstrates the practical application of embedded systems in security and automation.
It is useful for home security, smart access control and appliance protection, and help students understand button interfacing, LCD communication and relay control using Arduino.
In this project we have designed an LCD based sensor display system using Arduino and a 16 by two I Superscript 2C LCD.
The main objective of this project is to monitor environmental parameters and display them in real time.
In an LCD screen, the system uses a DHT 11 sensor to measure temperature and humidity, and an LDR sensor to detect light intensity in the surrounding environment.
These sensor values are continuously read by the Arduino Uno and processed internally.
Instead of using many wires, this project uses I Superscript 2C communication, which allows the LCD to work using only two data lines, SDA and SCL.
This makes the circuit simple, compact and more reliable, especially for IoT and embedded system applications.
The measured temperature.

Humidity and light intensity values are displayed on the 16 by 2 LCD in an easy to understand format, allowing users to monitor environmental conditions without the need for a serial monitor or computer connection.
This type of project is widely used in smart homes, whether monitoring systems, classrooms, greenhouses and industrial automation panels.
It is an excellent project for students and beginners to understand sensor interfacing I Superscript 2C communication and real time data display using Arduino.
Hello my dear friends, today I am presenting my project called Automatic Light Control System.
The aim of this project is to automatically turn a light on or off based on surrounding light conditions to save electricity.
In this project, an LDR sensor detects the light intensity and sends its value to the microcontroller.
When the surroundings become dark, the LDR value decreases and the microcontroller activates the relay, which works as an electrically operated switch and turns the light on.
When sufficient light is present, the relay turns off and the light switches off automatically.
The relay is connected using calm and and no terminals along with the resistor for safety.
This project is very useful for street lights, home automation and energy saving applications.

In this project we are implementing a temperature based LED control project using Arduino Uno, DHT 11 sensor and a relay module where an LED turns on automatically when the temperature rises above a set limit.
Arduino Uno acts as the controller, DHT 11 works as the temperature sensor and the relay acts as an electrically operated switch.
The DHT 11 sensor is connected with its VCC to 5V, data pin to digital pin, D7 and G&D to ground.
The relay module is connected with in one to D8BCC to 5V and G&D to G&D, and since the relay is a low level trigger module, it turns on when the lowest signal is applied.
The LED is connected through the normally open terminal of the relay, with its positive connected to 5V through a resistor and its negative connected to the.
Now terminal while Cam is connected to ground.
In the code, the DHT library is used to read the temperature value and Arduino continuously checks if the temperature exceeds 30C.
If it does, Arduino sends a low signal to the relay pin, turning on the relay and lighting the LED's and if the temperature.
Good morning my dear friends.
Today I am very happy to present my project titled Relay Controlled LED System using a Microcontroller.
The main objective of this project is to understand how a relay can be used as an electrically operated.
Switch to control devices safely and efficiently.
In this system, each LED has two terminals known as the anode and a cathode.
The cathode of each LED is connected directly to ground, while the anode is connected through a 220 ohm current limiting resistor to the calm terminal of the relay.
The no or normally open terminal of the relay is connected to a 5 Volt power supply.
When the relay is in the off state, the circuit remains open so no current flows.
And the LED stays off.

When the microcontroller sends a signal to the relay through the programmed code, the relay turns on and the comment and no terminals get connected, completing the circuit and allowing current to flow through the resistor and LED, causing the LED to light up.
In this project we are implementing a button controlled relay project using Arduino Uno and a 2 channel relay module where a push button is used to manually control the relay operation.
Arduino Uno acts as the controller the push button.
Acts as an input device and the relay module is used to switch external electrical devices.
The relay module is a 5 Volt optic coupler based low level trigger relay, meaning the relay turns on when the input signal is low.
For wiring, the push button is connected between digital pin D2 and G&D.
Relay in one is connected to D8, in two to D9, while VCC and GND D of the relay are connected to 5V and G&D of Arduino.
In the code the button pen is configured as input_pull up so the pin reads high.
Normally and low, when the button is pressed, both relay pins are set as output and initially kept off by sending high signals.

Inside the loop function, Arduino continuously reads the button state and when the button is pressed it sends low signals to both relay pins to turn them on, and when the button is released it sends high signals to turn them off.
This project helps students understand digital input reading, low level relay control, and basic manual automation concepts.

In this project we are working on a 2 channel relay on and off control project using Arduino Uno where Arduino Uno acts as the main controller and a fivefold optocoupler based low level trigger relay module is used to control electrical devices.
The relay module is connected such that in one is connected to digital pin D8, in two is connected to digital pin, D9DC is connected to 5V and G&D is connected to G&D.

In the Arduino code we 1st declare 2 integer variables to store the relay pin numbers and then inside the setup function we set both pins as output using the pin mode function and keep both relays off initially by sending high signals because this relay works on low level triggering.
In the loop function, Arduino sends a low signal to pin D8 to turn on relay one while keeping relay 2 off.
Then after a delay of two seconds, it turns relay one off and sends a low signal to pin D9 to turn on relay 2, and after another delay it sends high signals to both pins to turn both relays off.
This process keeps repeating continuously, allowing us to observe the relay switching through LED indicators and clicking sounds.
And through this project, students learn how digital output pins work, how low level triggered relays operate, and how Arduino can be used for basic automation and control applications.

In this project we are creating a simple alert system using Arduino, a push button, an RGB LED and a buzzer.
This system is useful for emergency alarms, security systems and classroom call buttons where a person can press a button to give an alert.
In the code we define the button pin RGB.
LED pins and buzzer pin and set them as input and output in the setup function.
In the loop function, Arduino continuously checks the button state.
When the button is pressed, the system goes into alert mode, the red color of the RGB LED turns on and the buzzer starts beeping.
When the button is not pressed, the system stays in safe mode, the green LED turns on, and the buzzer remains off.
For wiring, we connect the button to pin 2 and ground, the RGB red pen to pin 9, green pen to pen 10, the common pin to ground, and the buzzer to pin 8 and ground.
After uploading the code, we test the system by pressing the button and observing the red light and buzzer and releasing the button to see the green light and buzzer off.
This project helps us understand how input and output devices work in Arduino.

Symbols.
The IR receiver is also initialized on pin 6 and both servos are set to their starting positions, so the crane is in a stable state.
Inside the forever loop, the Arduino keeps checking if any data is received from the IR remote.
Whenever a button is pressed, the IR receiver reads the hex value of that button and refreshes for the next command.
Each hex value is linked to a specific action.
For example, when 1 button is pressed, the OLED shows a symbol and a servo on pin 13 rotates slightly to move the crane left or right.

At the same time, the OLED display updates to show arrows or icons so we can visually understand what action the crane is performing.

This project helps us learn how IR remote communication works, how different inputs can control motors, and how multiple components like servos and OLED displays can work together to create a smart machine.
In this project we create an automatic CSI using a Control Board and a servo motor.
A seesaw normally moves up and down when children push with their feet, but here the movement is controlled electronically.
The servo motor is connected to pin 13 of the main board, with its power and ground properly connected.
When the program starts, the board sends angle and delay commands to the servo motor.
By changing the angle value, the servo rotates in a specific direction and speed, which makes one side of the seesaw rise while the other side falls.
An angle close to 90 slows or stops the rotation, while values lower or higher than 90 control the direction and speed.
With the added delay, the motion becomes smooth and continuous, giving the seesaw A realistic up and down movement.
This project helps students understand how servo motors work, how angles control motion, and how simple coding can automate mechanical movements in real life models.
This rope skipping machine uses a joystick module, a 360 servo motor, and a passive buzzer to create an automatic skipping system.
The joystick works using I2C communication and provides 2 analog values X&Y ranging from zero to 1023 along with a digital button output in the neutral position.
Both X&Y values are around 512.
The 360 servo motor is connected to pin D13.
And is controlled by changing its angle value.
When the servo angle is set to 90, the motor stops rotating.
If the angle is less than 90, the servo rotates in One Direction and if it is greater than 90 it rotates in the opposite direction.
By changing how far the value is from 90, the speed of rotation can be increased or decreased.
In the program, the joystick values are continuously read inside a loop.
If the X axis value is greater than 512, the rope rotates in One Direction.
If it is less than 512, the rope rotates in the opposite direction.
This allows the skipping direction and speed to be controlled smoothly using the joystick.
When the joystick button is pressed, the passive buzzer plays a sound giving audio feedback to the user.

More dynamic and versatile from lighting up the LED to controlling servo.
Now I'm going to explain each and everything about PWM pins, how those PWM pins work.
So the Arduino board have total 14 digital pins, but we have 6 PWM.
Means which are special pins for Arduino Uno.

PWM pins are crucial for controlling devices that required a range of values instead of a simple on off state such as adjusting the brightness of an LED, controlling the speed of a bio motor or creating analog like output for audio signals.
The PWM pins can be identified.
By the tilt symbol marked next to pin number on the Arduino board.
As you can see we have a different symbols on our few digital pins like 356910 and 11.
Now what is PWM?
PWM stands for Pulse Width Modulation.
It is a method used by microcontroller to create an average.
Voltage that appears analog.
The idea is to turn a digital signal on and off repeatedly to generate a square wave by varying the proportion of time the signal is on versus off.
You can change the output also, for example if the signal is on for 5060% of the time.
And off for 50% of the time, you get a 50% duty cycle, which represent an average output voltage of about 2.5 Volt when the supply voltage is 5 Volt.
If the duty cycle is 25%, the average voltage would be approximately 1.25 V if the duty cycle is 75%.
The average voltage would be about 3.75 Volt.
This technique allowed the Arduino to approximate analog output even though it is a digital device that can only output high 5 Volt or low 0 Volt signals.
Now how to use PWM pins on the Arduino Uno in the Arduino programming language you.
Can use with analog write function to generate a PWM signal on any of the PWM pins.
The analog write function take two parameters, the pin number.
You want to output the Speedway signal to a value between 0 and 255, where 0 represents 0 duty cycle and 25.
Five represent 100% duty cycle.
Now what is duty cycle?
Duty cycle means 0% duty cycle is always off and 100% duty cycle is always on.
We have various kinds of application of PWM pens.
The first one is light brightness control.
Using PWM pin you can control.
The brightness of an LED's.
The higher the duty cycle the brighter the LED will appear.
Motor speed control.
You can also use PWM pin to control the speed of bio motor.
By adjusting the duty cycle you can make the motor run slower or more faster.
Audio signal generation.
PWM can be used to create.
Found by generating various frequencies.
By changing the duty cycle and frequency you can create different audio tunes.
Servo motor control PWM pin can also use to control server motors which require specific PWM pins to set their positions.
